title: HTTP/2 and HTTP/3
content:
Module 1, Lesson 4: HTTP/2 and HTTP/3

The Hook

HTTP/2 introduced multiplexing, header compression, and server push. HTTP/3 replaces TCP with QUIC, reducing latency especially on mobile networks.

In this lesson, we explore how HTTP/2 and HTTP/3 fits within the broader context of The Web's DNA: HTTP, DNS, and Request/Response. Building a solid understanding of these concepts will make you a more effective and confident full-stack developer.

The Concept

1. Core Principles

The core principles behind HTTP/2 and HTTP/3 are grounded in decades of software engineering practice. These principles — separation of concerns, single responsibility, and fail-fast design — provide a reliable foundation for production-quality code.

2. Implementation Patterns

Experienced developers recognise patterns for HTTP/2 and HTTP/3 that solve common problems efficiently. Understanding when to apply each pattern — and knowing the trade-offs — separates good developers from great ones.

3. Performance Implications

Every technical decision in HTTP/2 and HTTP/3 has performance implications. Understanding the performance characteristics of different approaches helps you make informed choices that scale well under real-world loads.

4. Security Considerations

Security must be considered from the first line of code, not bolted on at the end. The security considerations relevant to HTTP/2 and HTTP/3 are concrete and actionable: if you understand them, you can prevent the most common vulnerabilities.

5. Testing and Debugging

Effective testing of HTTP/2 and HTTP/3 components ensures reliability and enables confident refactoring. Debugging skills — knowing how to isolate, reproduce, and fix issues — are equally important and developed only through practice.

The Illustration

You have completed HTTP/2 and HTTP/3 within the The Web's DNA: HTTP, DNS, and Request/Response module. The key takeaways are: the core principles; common implementation patterns and their trade-offs; performance characteristics; security considerations; and testing approaches. Apply these insights in your next project and notice the difference in code quality and confidence. Continue to the next lesson to deepen your expertise.
